Question 98) Spiders, scorpions, ticks and mites are representatives of the arachnid class. These animals are terrestrial mostly and occupy the most varied habitats, such as high mountains, marshes, deserts and sandy soils. They may have been the first representatives of the Arthropoda phylum to inhabit the dry land.
The characteristic that justifies the adaptive success of this group in the occupation of the terrestrial environment is the presence of
A) Chelices and pedipalpos that coordinate body movement.
B) Excretion of uric acid that gives stability to body pH.
C) exoskeleton consisting of chitin that assists in body water control.
D) open blood circulation that prevents dehydration of bodily tissues.
E) ganglion nervous system that promotes the central coordination of body movement.
